thread.title: Chico parole agent saves life using Narcan - Inside CDCR
thread.title_full: Chico parole agent saves life using Narcan - Inside CDCR

author: Don Chaddock, Inside CDCR editor
title: Chico parole agent saves life using Narcan - Inside CDCR
text: In April, Parole Agents Huey and Whittaker were working in Chico when they noticed two men attempting to render aid on an unconscious man. Huey took action, heading to the scene while his partner called 911. Assessing the victim, Huey thought he might need CPR, then he spotted one of the men with an empty Narcan canister. After discovering the man may have overdosed on drugs, the people who were helping at the scene told Huey they had only administered one Narcan dose. Immediately, Huey gave the man two additional doses while waiting for emergency medical services (EMS) to arrive. The agent could see the victim, while unconscious, was beginning to breathe again. Once EMS arrived and began to transport the man to the hospital, the victim regained consciousness. When asked about his experience, Huey stated said he could remain calm due to the training he received through the Department. “With the ever-growing unfortunate drug addiction and drug use in our community, I am sad to say we see it frequently,” he said. Huey has been trained in Narcan use and is also a CPR/First Aid instructor. The Division of Adult Parole Operations extends appreciation and thanks to the quick actions of Agents Huey and Whittaker. Submitted by Division of Adult Parole Operations [Learn more about CDCR’s parole agents.](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/category/division-of-adult-parole-operations/) Follow CDCR on [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/CACorrections/featured), [X (formerly Twitter)](https://twitter.com/cacorrections). Listen to the [CDCR Unlocked podcast](https://rss.com/podcasts/cdcrunlocked/). [Parole success requires community partners](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/06/13/parole-success-requires-community-partners/) For reentry success, rural parole offices like the Redding Parole Unit collaborate with community partners and other agencies. “(We are) getting them clothed, housed, fed and meeting their basic needs so they can better focus on reentry,” said Justin Benson, Parole Agent II. [Ventura Training Center staff visits camps](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/06/05/ventura-training-center-staff-visits-camps/) Ventura Training Center (VTC) staff embarked on a four-day trip through Central California to visit CDCR conservation camps and firehouses to discuss the training center’s reentry opportunities. [Meet Justin Benson, Parole Agent II](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/05/24/meet-justin-benson-parole-agent-ii/) Justin Benson knows the people served by the Redding Parole Unit, mainly because he lives and works in the community as a parole agent II. For seven years, he’s been with the Division of Adult Parole Operations and previously did an 11-year stint with the Shasta County Probation Department. [DAPO raises funds for mental health](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/05/22/dapo-raises-funds-for-mental-health/) During the third annual Division of Adult Parole Operations (DAPO) Be Well mental health initiative, $3,250 was raised for the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI).
